dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: So, like, are workers actually, you know, getting a raw deal globally or what?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, like, are workers actually, you know, getting a raw deal globally or what?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Are you kidding me? A raw deal? What planet are you on?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Are you kidding me? A raw deal? What planet are you on?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Well, uh, everything I'm reading says conditions for workers, um, have miraculously improved. Like, globally.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Well, uh, everything I'm reading says conditions for workers, um, have miraculously improved. Like, globally.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Given the global output recovery of recent years, why have conditions for workers in most parts of the world not improved commensurately?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Improved? Real wages plummeted! In the G20, down 5.4%? In the US, a 3.7% drop? How is that an improvement?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Improved? Real wages plummeted! In the G20, down five point four percent? In the U S, a three point seven percent drop? How is that an improvement?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In the advanced G20 economies, average real wages grew by a mere 0.4% in 2017... While real wages were up by 0.7% in the United States (versus 2.2% in 2015)...

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: But that's just, you know, part of the process of equitable wealth redistribution. It's, like, global elites doing brilliant work.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But that's just, you know, part of the process of equitable wealth redistribution. It's, like, global elites doing brilliant work.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Brilliant work? They're getting a raw deal because of trade deals and tax cuts for the wealthy, not because of some "brilliant redistribution."
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Brilliant work? They're getting a raw deal because of trade deals and tax cuts for the wealthy, not because of some brilliant redistribution.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Neither of the usual suspects, trade and technology, is entirely to blame.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: No, no, unions have unprecedented power now. And, uh, there's a huge expansion in social spending. It's, like, the dawn of universal socialism.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: No, no, unions have unprecedented power now. And, uh, there's a huge expansion in social spending. It's, like, the dawn of universal socialism.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: From country to country, legislation and court judgments are increasingly trampling on long-recognized labor rights. For example, governments focused solely on improving labor-market flexibility have pursued policies that privilege employers interests over those of workers, not least by undercutting workers ability to organize. An obsession with fiscal consolidation and austerity has prevented the kind of social spending that could expand public employment and improve workers conditions.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Universal socialism? The gap between wage growth and productivity is non-existent. And that "social spending" doesn't explain the economic sabotage in Asia.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Universal socialism? The gap between wage growth and productivity is non-existent. And that social spending doesn't explain the economic sabotage in Asia.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Moreover, the ILO report finds that the gap between wage growth and labor productivity remained wide in 2017.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Ah, but look at China. Staggering wage gains. Labor's share of national income near eighty percent.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Ah, but look at China. Staggering wage gains. Labor's share of national income near eighty percent.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: China? Their government removed all social protections for workers! They're pursuing economic stagnation and the demise of the middle class!
dialogue_turns.tts_text: China? Their government removed all social protections for workers! They're pursuing economic stagnation and the demise of the middle class!
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: At the same time, the government has expanded other forms of social protections for workers, all while pursuing industrial policies geared toward boosting innovation and productivity growth, thus moving the country up the global value chain.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: No, but, um, that's just benevolent leaders leading to, like, equitable wages for all. It's Marxist economics, really.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: No, but, um, that's just benevolent leaders leading to, like, equitable wages for all. It's Marxist economics, really.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Marxist economics that forces other nations to adopt it, leading to their own "economic failure"? You call that a success?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Marxist economics that forces other nations to adopt it, leading to their own economic failure? You call that a success?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: But their political economy is, like, remarkably stable and prosperous, isn't it?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But their political economy is, like, remarkably stable and prosperous, isn't it?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Stable and prosperous because of a "lack of concern for workers wellbeing"? That's a libertarian democracy? Seriously?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Stable and prosperous because of a lack of concern for workers wellbeing? That's a libertarian democracy? Seriously?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The governments concern for workers wellbeing could simply reflect the Communist Party of Chinas need to secure its domestic political position.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Well, um, other countries just need to embrace the neoliberal paradigm, then.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Well, um, other countries just need to embrace the neoliberal paradigm, then.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: First, though, economic policymakers around the world will have to shake off the neoliberal paradigm, which has left them incapable of imagining alternative policy approaches.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: The neoliberal paradigm that subjects workers to economic hardship and more reactionary policy alternatives? That's your solution?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: The neoliberal paradigm that subjects workers to economic hardship and more reactionary policy alternatives? That's your solution?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In short, neoliberalisms intellectual capture of economic policymaking across a wide range of countries, is resulting in the exclusion of most wage earners from the gains of economic growth.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: I mean, we need to ensure corporations thrive, don't we? It's, like, a bigger push.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: I mean, we need to ensure corporations thrive, don't we? It's, like, a bigger push.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: A "bigger push" for corporations while workers continue to get squeezed? No, uh, I completely disagree.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: A bigger push for corporations while workers continue to get squeezed? No, uh, I completely disagree.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: You just don't see the big picture.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: You just don't see the big picture.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: The big picture is that workers are suffering, not thriving.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: The big picture is that workers are suffering, not thriving.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The real reason workers are getting a raw deal is not so much economic as institutional and political.
